pageContext.claim: “Murders in America’s largest cities dropped by 6 percent compared to 2016. The police departments here today have provided us with new homicide data showing steep declines over the last two years, including an estimated reduction of 16 percent in New Orleans, 27 percent in Newark, and 30 percent in Milwaukee.”
pageContext.analysis: It's unclear how Trump defines "America's largest cities" for this claim or where he gets the 6 percent figure. The FBI's Uniform Crime Report for 2017 shows that the total for homicides and nonnegligent manslaughters increased 1.6 percent in 2017 in cities, even as it declined overall nationwide. Cities with more than 1 million residents saw crime decline 8 percent. But cities with 500,000 to 1 million residents saw these crimes increase, as did cities with 25,000 to 250,000 residents. (The FBI's report for 2018 had not yet been released.)
